'Saturday Night Live' finally tackles the Harvey Weinstein scandal, harassment in Hollywood

Show Caption Hide Caption 'SNL' makes Kellyanne Conway a scary clown, fires at Weinstein Saturday Night Live's Kate McKinnon makes Kellyanne Conway a scary clown, while the show weighs in on the Harvey Weinstein scandal.

After initially side-stepping the Harvey Weinstein scandal, Saturday Night Live stepped up to address the issue this weekend.

In light of the allegations that Weinstein sexually assaulted and sexually harassed more than a dozen women, Leslie Jones’ Viola Davis, Cecily Strong’s Marion Cotillard and Kate McKinnon’s no-holds-barred Debette Goldry held a roundtable to discuss their experiences with sexual predation in the film industry.

"Having a lady in the family doesn’t make you some kind of hero!" #SNL pic.twitter.com/3gz9EUoC5H — Saturday Night Live (@nbcsnl) October 15, 2017

“Have I ever experienced sexual harassment in Hollywood? Good Friday, where do you want me to start?” Goldry exclaimed. “Women being harassed is Hollywood. Everything old is new again. Producers are abusing starlets. There’s Nazis marching in the street. And suddenly nude pantyhose are on-trend. I have never felt more at home.”

The allegations against Harvey Weinstein prompted a lot of reflection about harassment in Hollywood. #SNL pic.twitter.com/z98AeNV2tN — Saturday Night Live (@nbcsnl) October 15, 2017

Later, Goldry called out Weinstein directly: “I actually did have one meeting with Harvey. I was invited to his hotel room. When I arrived, he was naked hanging upside down from a monkey bar. Tried to trick me into thinking his genitals were actually his face. It almost worked. The resemblance is uncanny.”

RELATED: Kate McKinnon's Kellyanne Conway Is ‘It’ – and not in a good way

McKinnon’s Goldry wasn’t the only one with extraneous jokes about Weinstein’s appearance. "Weekend Update" star Michael Che also cracked, “It’s so hard to make jokes about sexual assault, but so easy to make jokes about a guy who looks like this. I mean, he looks like chewed-up bubblegum rolled in cat hair.”

For his part, Che’s co-anchor Colin Jost remained on-topic: “He needs a specialized facility where there are no women, no contact with the outside world, metal bars – and it’s a prison.”
